Hey! 

I submitted false with the explanation in [optional] saying:

"I assume for 3-3 the answer is also an integer, meaning in theory (would take long) we could search all integers in the following way: 0, 1, -1, 2, -2, ...

If "involving integers" includes stuff like dividing integers, the answer might not be an integer, and then the answer would be true."

Why can't all problems involving integers be solved using guess and check?
subject: Microquiz 1 Problem 3-3

content:
Some problems might not have an answer, but you don't know that in advance, and if the search space isn't bounded, then you may never be able to determine that.

As a contrived example, suppose the problem was to find x such that f(x) is even. If I give you an f() that's always odd, but don't tell you that, then guess-and-check would spin forever.

If we limited the set of x under consideration to a finite set of integers, though, then exhaustive enumeration would work (even if inefficiently).
The f() odd makes a lot of sense! thank you
